subject: Cybersecurity
title: Public Key Infrastructure: Trust on the Internet
description: A quick win: understand Public Key Infrastructure: Trust on the Internet.

hook.text: How do you know the website you're visiting is really your bank â€” and not an imposter?

buildup.text: PKI uses certificate authorities (CAs) to verify identities. Your browser trusts a chain of digital signatures.

discovery.text: When you see the padlock icon, a CA has vouched that the site's public key truly belongs to that domain.

twist.text: If a CA is compromised, all trust chain collapses. It happened with DigiNotar in 2011 â€“ Iran used fake certs to spy.

climax.text: PKI is deeply flawed but remains the best system we have for internet trust. It's trust built on trust.

punchline.text: That padlock means someone vouched for this site. Hopefully.

quiz.question: What role do certificate authorities play in PKI?
options: They verify that a public key belongs to a specific domain
